title: Jake_Gyllenhaal
content:
Life and career
Jacob Benjamin Gyllenhaal was born on December 19, 1980, in Los Angeles, California, United States, to screenwriter Naomi Foner (née Achs) and film director Stephen Gyllenhaal [5] [6] Actress Maggie Gyllenhaal, his older sister, appeared with him in the science fiction psychological thriller film Donnie Darko (2001) Gyllenhaal's father, who was raised as a Swedenborgian, is of Swedish and English descent and is a descendant of the Swedish noble Gyllenhaal family [7] His last ancestor to be born in Sweden was his great-great-grandfather, Anders Leonard Gyllenhaal [8] Gyllenhaal's mother is Jewish, [9] [10] [11] [12] and was born in New York City into an Ashkenazi Jewish family from Russia and Poland [13] [14] Gyllenhaal has said that he considers himself Jewish [15] [16] On his 13th birthday, Gyllenhaal performed a "Bar Mitzvah-like act, without the typical trappings", volunteering at a homeless shelter because his parents wanted to give him a sense of gratitude for his privileged lifestyle [17] [18]


1980–2000: Early life and career beginnings
Jacob Benjamin Gyllenhaal was born on December 19, 1980, in Los Angeles, California, United States, to screenwriter Naomi Foner (née Achs) and film director Stephen Gyllenhaal [5] [6] Actress Maggie Gyllenhaal, his older sister, appeared with him in the science fiction psychological thriller film Donnie Darko (2001) Gyllenhaal's father, who was raised as a Swedenborgian, is of Swedish and English descent and is a descendant of the Swedish noble Gyllenhaal family [7] His last ancestor to be born in Sweden was his great-great-grandfather, Anders Leonard Gyllenhaal [8] Gyllenhaal's mother is Jewish, [9] [10] [11] [12] and was born in New York City into an Ashkenazi Jewish family from Russia and Poland [13] [14] Gyllenhaal has said that he considers himself Jewish [15] [16] On his 13th birthday, Gyllenhaal performed a "Bar Mitzvah-like act, without the typical trappings", volunteering at a homeless shelter because his parents wanted to give him a sense of gratitude for his privileged lifestyle [17] [18]


2001–2004: Donnie Darko to the London stage
Donnie Darko, in which Gyllenhaal played his second lead role on film, was not a box office success on its initial 2001 release; eventually, the film became a cult favorite [24] Directed by Richard Kelly, the film is set in 1988 and stars Gyllenhaal as a troubled teenager who experiences visions of a 6-foot (1.8 m) tall rabbit named Frank who tells him that the world is coming to an end Gyllenhaal's performance was well received by critics; Gary Mairs of Culture Vulture wrote that he "manages the difficult trick of seeming both blandly normal and profoundly disturbed, often within the same scene." [25] [26]


2005–2011: Brokeback Mountain and leading roles
In 2005, Gyllenhaal was cast in the drama Proof, with co-stars Gwyneth Paltrow and Anthony Hopkins, where he played a graduate student in mathematics who tries to convince Paltrow's character to publish a revolutionary proof to a problem puzzling the mathematicians' community The film received a generally positive response He also starred in Sam Mendes's Jarhead, where Gyllenhaal played a U.S Marine during the first Gulf War The film garnered a favorable response; Stephen Hunter of The Washington Post praises Gyllenhaal's performance, writing, "He makes us see his character's intelligence", adding "he doesn't seem jealous of the camera's attention when it goes to others" [45]


2012–2018: Critical acclaim and Broadway debut
Gyllenhaal starred alongside Michael Peña in David Ayer's action thriller End of Watch, about two Los Angeles street cops The film, for which Gyllenhaal was also an executive producer, was released in September 2012 and received positive reviews, with Roger Ebert deeming it "one of the best police movies in recent years, a virtuoso fusion of performances and often startling action" and Salon's Andrew O'Hehir stating that the film was "at least the best cop movie since James Gray's We Own the Night, and very likely since Antoine Fuqua's memorable Training Day (which, not coincidentally, was written by Ayer)" [72] [73] To prepare for the role, Gyllenhaal took tactical training and participated in actual police ride-alongs with co-star Peña to help establish the language of the characters [74]


2019–present: Action and thriller films
Gyllenhaal reunited with Nightcrawler director Dan Gilroy in the thriller film Velvet Buzzsaw, in which he plays art critic Mort Vandewalt [105] The film premiered at the 2019 Sundance Film Festival and was distributed by Netflix Variety's Peter Debrudge opined that Gyllenhaal was "relishing another of those cartoonishly camp performances" [106] That same year, Gyllenhaal played comic book villain Mysterio / Quentin Beck in the superhero film Spider-Man: Far From Home, a sequel to Spider-Man: Homecoming, set within the Marvel Cinematic Universe [107] It was one of the highest-grossing films of the year [108] He appeared alongside Tom Sturridge in Sea Wall/A Life, a double bill of monologues by Nick Payne and Simon Stephens, at the Hudson Theatre on Broadway in 2019 [109] He garnered a Tony Award nomination for Best Actor in a Play for his performance [110] Gyllenhaal also lent his voice for the animation Spirit Untamed (2021) [111] That same year, he played detective Joe Baylor in the crime thriller The Guilty, a remake of the Danish film of the same name [112]


Public image
Gyllenhaal was named one of People's "50 Most Beautiful People" in 2006 [121] He was also listed in People's "Hottest Bachelors of 2006" [122] In April 2012, Shalom Life ranked him number six on its list of "the 50 most talented, intelligent, funny, and gorgeous Jewish men in the world" [123] He was ranked number 35 in Empire's poll of The 100 Sexiest Movie Stars in 2013 [124] In another poll conducted by Glamour, Gyllenhaal was selected as one of the Sexiest Men of The Year 2018 [125]


Personal life
Gyllenhaal's sister Maggie is married to actor Peter Sarsgaard, Gyllenhaal's co-star in Jarhead and Rendition [126] In December 2006, Gyllenhaal and his sister escaped a fire that destroyed Manka's Inverness Lodge, a famed lodge and restaurant in Inverness, California, at which they were vacationing The two were among a dozen or so guests who fled after the fire, sparked by a falling tree, broke out at about 3 a.m Co-owner and celebrity chef Daniel DeLong said the pair were supportive despite having to brave the wind and cold "Jake was helping me pull things out of the fire," DeLong said [127]


Family and relationships
Gyllenhaal's sister Maggie is married to actor Peter Sarsgaard, Gyllenhaal's co-star in Jarhead and Rendition [126] In December 2006, Gyllenhaal and his sister escaped a fire that destroyed Manka's Inverness Lodge, a famed lodge and restaurant in Inverness, California, at which they were vacationing The two were among a dozen or so guests who fled after the fire, sparked by a falling tree, broke out at about 3 a.m Co-owner and celebrity chef Daniel DeLong said the pair were supportive despite having to brave the wind and cold "Jake was helping me pull things out of the fire," DeLong said [127]


Political views and other interests
Gyllenhaal once filmed a commercial for Rock the Vote and, along with his sister, visited the University of Southern California to urge students to vote in the 2004 U.S presidential election [142] He also campaigned for Democratic Party presidential nominee John Kerry [143] He has said that "it frustrates me when actors talk politics; I'm political and I make choices in my movies that I think are political I try and say things with what I do Rightly or wrongly, young actors have all the power." [6] In an interview, he remarked that "it's a sad time when actors are politicians and politicians are actors" [144] In the 2018 midterm elections, Gyllenhaal endorsed U.S Senate candidate Beto O'Rourke His endorsement came in the form of a Facebook post that included a picture of him in a "BETO" shirt and a caption that also endorsed Stacey Abrams, Andrew Gillum, Kyrsten Sinema, and Jacky Rosen in their respective Senate or gubernatorial elections [145]


Acting credits and awards
Gyllenhaal's most acclaimed films, according to the review aggregate site Rotten Tomatoes, include October Sky (1999), Donnie Darko (2001), Lovely & Amazing (2002), Brokeback Mountain (2005), Zodiac (2007), Source Code (2011), End of Watch (2012), Nightcrawler (2014), and Stronger (2017) He has received numerous accolades, including a BAFTA Film Award, an Independent Spirit Award, and nominations for an Academy Award, two Golden Globe Awards, three Screen Actors Guild Awards and three Tony Awards.


References


External links

**Jake Gyllenhaal**

Jake Gyllenhaal is a talented American actor, born on December 19, 1980, in Los Angeles, California, to screenwriter Naomi Foner and film director Stephen Gyllenhaal. He is the younger brother of actress Maggie Gyllenhaal, who has appeared alongside him in several films. Gyllenhaal's ancestry is Swedish and English, with his father's family being descendants of the Swedish noble Gyllenhaal family.

**Early Life and Career Beginnings**

Gyllenhaal was born in Los Angeles, California, to a family of artists. His father, Stephen Gyllenhaal, was a film director and screenwriter, and his mother, Naomi Foner, was a screenwriter. Gyllenhaal's sister, Maggie, is an actress who has appeared in films such as "Secretary" and "The Dark Knight." Gyllenhaal's early life was marked by a passion for acting, and he began performing in school plays and community theater productions.

Gyllenhaal's first major film role was in the 1991 film "City Slickers," where he played the son of Billy Crystal's character. He continued to appear in films throughout the 1990s, including "October Sky" and "Donnie Darko." However, it was his role in "Donnie Darko" that brought him widespread recognition and critical acclaim.

**Donnie Darko to the London Stage**

"Donnie Darko" is a science fiction psychological thriller film directed by Richard Kelly. The film stars Gyllenhaal as Donnie Darko, a troubled teenager who experiences visions of a 6-foot-tall rabbit named Frank. The film was released in 2001 and initially received mixed reviews, but it has since become a cult classic.

Gyllenhaal's performance in "Donnie Darko" was widely praised by critics, with many noting his ability to convey a sense of vulnerability and intensity. He has said in interviews that he was drawn to the film's complex characters and themes, and that he felt a sense of responsibility to bring the character of Donnie Darko to life.

**2005-2011: Brokeback Mountain and Leading Roles**

In 2005, Gyllenhaal starred in the drama "Brokeback Mountain," which was directed by Ang Lee and co-starred Heath Ledger. The film tells the story of two cowboys who fall in love in rural Wyoming, and it received widespread critical acclaim. Gyllenhaal's performance in the film was praised by critics, with many noting his ability to convey a sense of vulnerability and sensitivity.

Gyllenhaal's other notable roles during this period include "Proof" and "Jarhead." In "Proof," he played a graduate student in mathematics who tries to convince a young woman to publish a revolutionary proof to a problem puzzling the mathematicians' community. In "Jarhead," he played a U.S Marine during the first Gulf War.

**2012-2018: Critical Acclaim and Broadway Debut**

In 2012, Gyllenhaal starred in the action thriller "End of Watch," which was directed by David Ayer and co-starred Michael Peña. The film follows two Los Angeles street cops as they patrol the city and encounter a range of challenges and dangers. Gyllenhaal's performance in the film was praised by critics, with many noting his ability to convey a sense of intensity and vulnerability.

Gyllenhaal's other notable roles during this period include "Nightcrawler" and "Stronger." In "Nightcrawler," he played a young man who becomes obsessed with capturing violent and sensational footage for a local news station. In "Stronger," he played a Boston Marathon bombing survivor who struggles to come to terms with his new reality.

**2019-Present: Action and Thriller Films**

In 2019, Gyllenhaal starred in the thriller "Velvet Buzzsaw," which was directed by Dan Gilroy and co-starred Renée Elise Goldsberry. The film follows an art critic who becomes embroiled in a murder mystery involving a wealthy art collector. Gyllenhaal's performance in the film was praised by critics, with many noting his ability to convey a sense of intensity and sophistication.

Gyllenhaal's other notable roles during this period include "Spider-Man: Far From Home" and "The Guilty." In "Spider-Man: Far From Home," he played a comic book villain named Mysterio. In "The Guilty," he played a detective who must solve a crime while communicating with his partner over the phone.

**Public Image**

Gyllenhaal has been named one of People's "50 Most Beautiful People" and has been listed in People's "Hottest Bachelors" poll. He has also been ranked number six on Shalom Life's list of "the 50 most talented, intelligent, funny, and gorgeous Jewish men in the world." In 2013, he was ranked number 35 in Empire's poll of "The 100 Sexiest Movie Stars."

**Personal Life**

Gyllenhaal's sister, Maggie, is married to actor Peter Sarsgaard, who has appeared in films such as "Jarhead" and "Rendition." In 2006, Gyllenhaal and his sister escaped a fire that destroyed Manka's Inverness Lodge, a famed lodge and restaurant in Inverness, California.

**Family and Relationships**

Gyllenhaal's sister, Maggie, is married to actor Peter Sarsgaard. Gyllenhaal's other notable relationships include his romance with actresses Reese Witherspoon and Kirsten Dunst.

**Political Views and Other Interests**

Gyllenhaal has been active in politics, having campaigned for Democratic Party presidential nominee John Kerry in 2004. He has also supported various charitable causes, including the American Cancer Society and the Nature Conservancy.

**Acting Credits and Awards**

Gyllenhaal's most acclaimed films include "October Sky," "Donnie Darko," "Lovely & Amazing," "Brokeback Mountain," "Zodiac," "Source Code," "End of Watch," "Nightcrawler," and "Stronger." He has received numerous accolades, including a BAFTA Film Award, an Independent Spirit Award, and nominations for an Academy Award, two Golden Globe Awards, three Screen Actors Guild Awards, and three Tony Awards.

In 2005, Gyllenhaal was cast in the drama Proof, with co-stars Gwyneth Paltrow and Anthony Hopkins, where he played a graduate student in mathematics who tries to convince Paltrow's character to publish a revolutionary proof to a problem puzzling the mathematicians' community The film received a generally positive response He also starred in Sam Mendes's Jarhead, where Gyllenhaal played a U.S Marine during the first Gulf War The film garnered a favorable response; Stephen Hunter of The Washington Post praises Gyllenhaal's performance, writing, "He makes us see his character's intelligence", adding "he doesn't seem jealous of the camera's attention when it goes to others" [45]


2012–2018: Critical acclaim and Broadway debut
Gyllenhaal starred alongside Michael Peña in David Ayer's action thriller End of Watch, about two Los Angeles street cops The film, for which Gyllenhaal was also an executive producer, was released in September 2012 and received positive reviews, with Roger Ebert deeming it "one of the best police movies in recent years, a virtuoso fusion of performances and often startling action" and Salon's Andrew O'Hehir stating that the film was "at least the best cop movie since James Gray's We Own the Night, and very likely since Antoine Fuqua's memorable Training Day (which, not coincidentally, was written by Ayer)" [72] [73] To prepare for the role, Gyllenhaal took tactical training and participated in actual police ride-alongs with co-star Peña to help establish the language of the characters [74]


2019–present: Action and thriller films
Gyllenhaal reunited with Nightcrawler director Dan Gilroy in the thriller film Velvet Buzzsaw, in which he plays art critic Mort Vandewalt [105] The film premiered at the 2019 Sundance Film Festival and was distributed by Netflix Variety's Peter Debrudge opined that Gyllenhaal was "relishing another of those cartoonishly camp performances" [106] That same year, Gyllenhaal played comic book villain Mysterio / Quentin Beck in the superhero film Spider-Man: Far From Home, a sequel to Spider-Man: Homecoming, set within the Marvel Cinematic Universe [107] It was one of the highest-grossing films of the year [108] He appeared alongside Tom Sturridge in Sea Wall/A Life, a double bill of monologues by Nick Payne and Simon Stephens, at the Hudson Theatre on Broadway in 2019 [109] He garnered a Tony Award nomination for Best Actor in a Play for his performance [110] Gyllenhaal also lent his voice for the animation Spirit Untamed (2021) [111] That same year, he played detective Joe Baylor in the crime thriller The Guilty, a remake of the Danish film of the same name [112]


Public image
Gyllenhaal was named one of People's "50 Most Beautiful People" in 2006 [121] He was also listed in People's "Hottest Bachelors of 2006" [122] In April 2012, Shalom Life ranked him number six on its list of "the 50 most talented, intelligent, funny, and gorgeous Jewish men in the world" [123] He was ranked number 35 in Empire's poll of The 100 Sexiest Movie Stars in 2013 [124] In another poll conducted by Glamour, Gyllenhaal was selected as one of the Sexiest Men of The Year 2018 [125]


Personal life
Gyllenhaal's sister Maggie is married to actor Peter Sarsgaard, Gyllenhaal's co-star in Jarhead and Rendition [126] In December 2006, Gyllenhaal and his sister escaped a fire that destroyed Manka's Inverness Lodge, a famed lodge and restaurant in Inverness, California, at which they were vacationing The two were among a dozen or so guests who fled after the fire, sparked by a falling tree, broke out at about 3 a.m Co-owner and celebrity chef Daniel DeLong said the pair were supportive despite having to brave the wind and cold "Jake was helping me pull things out of the fire," DeLong said [127]


Family and relationships
Gyllenhaal's sister Maggie is married to actor Peter Sarsgaard, Gyllenhaal's co-star in Jarhead and Rendition [126] In December 2006, Gyllenhaal and his sister escaped a fire that destroyed Manka's Inverness Lodge, a famed lodge and restaurant in Inverness, California, at which they were vacationing The two were among a dozen or so guests who fled after the fire, sparked by a falling tree, broke out at about 3 a.m Co-owner and celebrity chef Daniel DeLong said the pair were supportive despite having to brave the wind and cold "Jake was helping me pull things out of the fire," DeLong said [127]


Political views and other interests
Gyllenhaal once filmed a commercial for Rock the Vote and, along with his sister, visited the University of Southern California to urge students to vote in the 2004 U.S presidential election [142] He also campaigned for Democratic Party presidential nominee John Kerry [143] He has said that "it frustrates me when actors talk politics; I'm political and I make choices in my movies that I think are political I try and say things with what I do Rightly or wrongly, young actors have all the power." [6] In an interview, he remarked that "it's a sad time when actors are politicians and politicians are actors" [144] In the 2018 midterm elections, Gyllenhaal endorsed U.S Senate candidate Beto O'Rourke His endorsement came in the form of a Facebook post that included a picture of him in a "BETO" shirt and a caption that also endorsed Stacey Abrams, Andrew Gillum, Kyrsten Sinema, and Jacky Rosen in their respective Senate or gubernatorial elections [145]


Acting credits and awards
Gyllenhaal's most acclaimed films, according to the review aggregate site Rotten Tomatoes, include October Sky (1999), Donnie Darko (2001), Lovely & Amazing (2002), Brokeback Mountain (2005), Zodiac (2007), Source Code (2011), End of Watch (2012), Nightcrawler (2014), and Stronger (2017) He has received numerous accolades, including a BAFTA Film Award, an Independent Spirit Award, and nominations for an Academy Award, two Golden Globe Awards, three Screen Actors Guild Awards and three Tony Awards.

title: Nikita_Mazepin
content:
Personal life
He is the son of Dmitry Mazepin, [2] a Belarusian-Russian oligarch businessman who is the former core shareholder and former chairman of Uralchem [3] [4]


Sanctions
In March 2022, Mazepin and his father, Dmitry, were included on the EU sanctions list following the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine [15] He was also later sanctioned by the United Kingdom and Canada over the same reason [16] [17] In April 2022, a residential compound owned by Nikita and Dmitry in Portisco, Sardinia that was worth more than $114 million was seized by Italian authorities [18] Following his dismissal from Formula One, Mazepin created "We Compete as One", a foundation to support athletes excluded for "non-sporting decisions" [19]


Career
Having won the Russian Karting championship, Mazepin started his international karting career in 2011 in the Trofeo Andrea Margutti [24] He quickly moved up the ranks, driving in the CIK-FIA Karting European Championship in the KF3 class in just his second year of competition [25] In 2013 he finished fourth in the KFJ-category of the WSK Super Master Series, [26] and in 2014, his final year of karting, he came 2nd in the Karting World Championship to Lando Norris [27]


Karting career
Having won the Russian Karting championship, Mazepin started his international karting career in 2011 in the Trofeo Andrea Margutti [24] He quickly moved up the ranks, driving in the CIK-FIA Karting European Championship in the KF3 class in just his second year of competition [25] In 2013 he finished fourth in the KFJ-category of the WSK Super Master Series, [26] and in 2014, his final year of karting, he came 2nd in the Karting World Championship to Lando Norris [27]


Lower formulae
Mazepin made his car racing debut in the MRF Challenge Formula 2000 at the end of 2014, driving in the first round of the series and grabbing his first podium in just his second race of his single-seater career He then made the switch to compete in the Toyota Racing Series with ETEC Motorsport, where he finished 18th in the drivers' standings [28] He followed that up by racing for Josef Kaufmann Racing in the Formula Renault Northern European Cup alongside Louis Delétraz, Kevin Jörg and fellow rookie Dries Vanthoor [29] Mazepin scored one podium with a third-place finish at the Red Bull Ring, and ended up twelfth in the championship.


Formula 3 European Championship
In 2016, Mazepin competed in the 2016 FIA Formula 3 European Championship for Hitech Grand Prix [30] He scored four points-scoring finishes and finished 20th in the championship, last of all full-time entrants After being blocked during a session by Callum Ilott, Mazepin got into an altercation with the other driver, during which Mazepin hit Ilott in the face, resulting in a ban from the first race of the Hungaroring meeting The sanction itself was controversial, with Frits van Amersfoort, boss of Ilott's team, believing the decision to be too lenient, calling it "a ridiculous decision by the stewards" [31] [32]


2016
In 2016, Mazepin competed in the 2016 FIA Formula 3 European Championship for Hitech Grand Prix [30] He scored four points-scoring finishes and finished 20th in the championship, last of all full-time entrants After being blocked during a session by Callum Ilott, Mazepin got into an altercation with the other driver, during which Mazepin hit Ilott in the face, resulting in a ban from the first race of the Hungaroring meeting The sanction itself was controversial, with Frits van Amersfoort, boss of Ilott's team, believing the decision to be too lenient, calling it "a ridiculous decision by the stewards" [31] [32]


2017
Despite the controversies of 2016, Mazepin was retained for another season [33] He improved significantly compared to his first year, scoring 108 points and finishing on the podium on three occasions He finished in tenth, one place behind teammate Ralf Aron.


GP3 Series
Mazepin moved to GP3 in 2018 to race for ART Grand Prix alongside Callum Ilott, Jake Hughes and eventual champion Anthoine Hubert [34] He won four races, the most of any driver that year, and finished second in the championship, only 16 points behind Hubert [35] Furthermore, he helped his team secure the title in the team championship [36]


FIA Formula 2 Championship
In 2019, Mazepin progressed to Formula 2 to partner Nyck de Vries at ART Grand Prix [37] His season was marked by causing an accident with Nobuharu Matsushita in the Sochi sprint race While his teammate ended up winning the championship, Mazepin ended the season in 18th place with 11 points.


2019
In 2019, Mazepin progressed to Formula 2 to partner Nyck de Vries at ART Grand Prix [37] His season was marked by causing an accident with Nobuharu Matsushita in the Sochi sprint race While his teammate ended up winning the championship, Mazepin ended the season in 18th place with 11 points.


2020
In 2020, he signed for the new Hitech Grand Prix Team to drive alongside Italian Luca Ghiotto His first podium came at the Hungaroring with second place, before taking his first F2 victory in Britain Mazepin also won the feature race at Mugello On the final lap of the Belgian feature race, he pushed Carlin driver Yuki Tsunoda wide, and was given a five-second time penalty, denying himself victory [38] [39]


Formula One
Mazepin was named test driver of Sahara Force India in 2016 and made his Formula One testing debut in the in-season test at Silverstone, where he achieved a personal best lap time of 1:31.561 [40] [41] He stayed in that role for the following two seasons, racking up 100 laps at the Hungaroring in 2017 and 51 in 2018 at the same track [42] The following year he took part for Mercedes in the 2019 Barcelona test, where he topped the timing sheets with a time of 1:15.775 [43] [44]


Haas (2021)
Mazepin joined Haas F1 Team for 2021 on a multi-year deal, partnering Mick Schumacher [45] He chose the number 9 as his permanent racing number Mazepin competed under a neutral flag representing the Russian Automobile Federation in the 2021 Formula One World Championship after the Court of Arbitration for Sport upheld a World Anti-Doping Agency ban on Russia competing at World Championships in December 2020 due to state-sponsored doping of Russian athletes [46]


2021
Mazepin joined Haas F1 Team for 2021 on a multi-year deal, partnering Mick Schumacher [45] He chose the number 9 as his permanent racing number Mazepin competed under a neutral flag representing the Russian Automobile Federation in the 2021 Formula One World Championship after the Court of Arbitration for Sport upheld a World Anti-Doping Agency ban on Russia competing at World Championships in December 2020 due to state-sponsored doping of Russian athletes [46]


2022
Mazepin was contracted to compete for Haas in the 2022 Formula One World Championship again under a neutral flag representing the Russian Automobile Federation like the 2021 championship, however on 5 March, Haas terminated both his contract and Uralkali's title sponsorship as part of the larger global response to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine [52] Mazepin expressed disappointment at the decision, remarking on social media that his "ongoing willingness to accept the conditions proposed in order to continue were completely ignored" [53] In a BBC interview, Mazepin stated that the sports sanctions were "cancel culture" against Russia [54] Mazepin also stated that he sees "tremendous risks in saying anything at all" regarding the Russian invasion of Ukraine [55] [56]


Rally raid
A self-professed rally raid fan, Mazepin participated in a test with Dakar Rally-winning truck team Kamaz Master in July 2021 [62] [63] Following his departure from Formula One in 2022, he expressed interest in switching to rally raid should he not return to F1 In his July 2022 interview with Match TV, Mazepin explained he intended to compete in off-road as long as he enjoyed it, and joked he would continue to do so if he could "physically walk and get into the car" as "there is no age limit in this sport." [58]


Asian Le Mans Series
In 2023, Mazepin returned to international motorsport, making his endurance racing debut in the Asian Le Mans Series with 99 Racing competing under a neutral flag [71] At the first race in Dubai, Mazepin, along with teammates Neel Jani and Gonçalo Gomes, finished on the podium, with Jani narrowly losing out on second to Charlie Eastwood during the final stint [72] He and Jani finished fourth in the LMP2 driver's championship with a sixth in the second Dubai race, followed by seventh and second in the two Abu Dhabi rounds.

article:
**Nikita Mazepin**

Nikita Mazepin is a Russian racing driver who has competed in various series, including Formula One. He is the son of Dmitry Mazepin, a Belarusian-Russian oligarch businessman who is the former core shareholder and former chairman of Uralchem.

**Personal Life**

Nikita Mazepin is the son of Dmitry Mazepin, a wealthy businessman who has been involved in various industries, including chemicals and mining. Mazepin's father is also the owner of the Russian company Uralchem, which is involved in the production of fertilizers and other chemicals. As a result, Nikita Mazepin has been exposed to a life of wealth and privilege from a young age.

**Sanctions**

In March 2022, Mazepin and his father, Dmitry, were included on the EU sanctions list following the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. The sanctions were imposed in response to the Russian government's actions, which were deemed to be a threat to regional stability and security. Mazepin was also subsequently sanctioned by the United Kingdom and Canada over the same reason.

**Career**

Mazepin's career in racing began in karting, where he won the Russian Karting championship. He then moved on to compete in international karting events, including the CIK-FIA Karting European Championship and the Karting World Championship. In 2014, he finished second in the Karting World Championship to Lando Norris.

**Karting Career**

Mazepin's karting career was marked by a number of impressive performances. He won the Russian Karting championship and then went on to compete in international events, including the CIK-FIA Karting European Championship and the Karting World Championship. In 2014, he finished second in the Karting World Championship to Lando Norris.

**Lower Formulae**

Mazepin made his car racing debut in the MRF Challenge Formula 2000 in 2014. He then moved on to compete in the Toyota Racing Series and the Formula Renault Northern European Cup. In 2016, he competed in the Formula 3 European Championship for Hitech Grand Prix.

**Formula 3 European Championship**

In 2016, Mazepin competed in the Formula 3 European Championship for Hitech Grand Prix. He scored four points-scoring finishes and finished 20th in the championship. He was involved in a controversy with Callum Ilott, who blocked him during a session. Mazepin got into an altercation with Ilott, which resulted in a ban from the first race of the Hungaroring meeting.

**2017**

Mazepin was retained for another season in 2017. He improved significantly compared to his first year, scoring 108 points and finishing on the podium on three occasions. He finished in tenth, one place behind teammate Ralf Aron.

**GP3 Series**

Mazepin moved to GP3 in 2018 to race for ART Grand Prix. He won four races and finished second in the championship, only 16 points behind Anthoine Hubert. He also helped his team secure the title in the team championship.

**FIA Formula 2 Championship**

In 2019, Mazepin progressed to Formula 2 to partner Nyck de Vries at ART Grand Prix. He scored 11 points and finished 18th in the championship.

**2020**

In 2020, Mazepin signed for the new Hitech Grand Prix Team to drive alongside Luca Ghiotto. He scored his first podium in the series at the Hungaroring and won the feature race at Silverstone.

**Formula One**

Mazepin was named test driver of Sahara Force India in 2016. He made his Formula One testing debut in the in-season test at Silverstone. He stayed in that role for the following two seasons, racking up 100 laps at the Hungaroring in 2017 and 51 in 2018 at the same track.

**Haas (2021)**

Mazepin joined Haas F1 Team for 2021 on a multi-year deal, partnering Mick Schumacher. He chose the number 9 as his permanent racing number.

**2022**

Mazepin was contracted to compete for Haas in the 2022 Formula One World Championship. However, on 5 March, Haas terminated both his contract and Uralkali's title sponsorship as part of the larger global response to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.

**Rally Raid**

Mazepin has expressed interest in competing in rally raid events. He participated in a test with Dakar Rally-winning truck team Kamaz Master in July 2021. Following his departure from Formula One in 2022, he expressed interest in switching to rally raid should he not return to F1.

**Asian Le Mans Series**

In 2023, Mazepin returned to international motorsport, making his endurance racing debut in the Asian Le Mans Series with 99 Racing. He finished on the podium in the first race and finished fourth in the LMP2 driver's championship.

**Karting Record**

Mazepin's karting career was marked by a number of impressive performances. He won the Russian Karting championship and finished second in the Karting World Championship in 2014.

**Racing Record**

Mazepin's car racing career has been marked by a number of impressive performances. He won the Formula 3 European Championship in 2017 and finished second in the GP3 Series in 2018.

**References**

This article is based on information from various sources, including Wikipedia and other online news outlets.

**External Links**

For more information on Nikita Mazepin, please visit the following websites:

* Wikipedia: Nikita_Mazepin
* Formula One: Nikita_Mazepin
* Instagram: @nikitamazepin

Premise
When a rising high school American football player from South L.A is recruited to play for Beverly Hills High, the wins, losses and struggles of two families from vastly different worlds—Crenshaw and Beverly Hills—begin to collide Inspired by the life of pro football player Spencer Paysinger [4]

Episodes
In September 2017, it was announced that the CW veteran Greg Berlanti had two pilots in development for the network, one of them inspired by the life of NFL football player Spencer Paysinger It was also revealed that April Blair would write and executive produce the untitled project, with Berlanti and Sarah Schechter executive producing [28] A pilot for the potential series, then called Spencer, was ordered in January 2018 [29] The pilot was ordered to series on May 11, 2018 [4] On October 2, 2018, it was reported that Blair had stepped down as showrunner due to "personal reasons" and was subsequently replaced with co-executive producer Nkechi Okoro Carroll, who was also made an executive producer [30] On October 8, 2018, The CW ordered five additional scripts for the series [31] On November 8, 2018, it was announced that The CW had ordered an additional three episodes of the series, bringing the first season total up to 16 episodes [32] On April 24, 2019, it was reported that The CW renewed the series for a second season [33] The second season premiered on October 7, 2019 [34] On October 8, 2019, The CW ordered three more episodes for the series' second season [35] On January 7, 2020, the series was renewed for a third season which premiered on January 18, 2021 [36] [37] On February 3, 2021, The CW renewed the series for a fourth season which premiered on October 25, 2021 [38] [39] On March 22, 2022, The CW renewed the series for a fifth season which premiered on October 10, 2022 [40] [41] On January 11, 2023, The CW renewed the series for a sixth season which premiered on April 1, 2024 [1] [2] The renewal was a part of the deal in which The CW was sold to Nexstar, [42] with the size of the sixth season being expanded from 13 to 15 episodes on April 22, 2024 [43] On June 3, 2024, The CW renewed the series for a 13-episode seventh season set to premiere in 2025 [3]


Production
In September 2017, it was announced that the CW veteran Greg Berlanti had two pilots in development for the network, one of them inspired by the life of NFL football player Spencer Paysinger It was also revealed that April Blair would write and executive produce the untitled project, with Berlanti and Sarah Schechter executive producing [28] A pilot for the potential series, then called Spencer, was ordered in January 2018 [29] The pilot was ordered to series on May 11, 2018 [4] On October 2, 2018, it was reported that Blair had stepped down as showrunner due to "personal reasons" and was subsequently replaced with co-executive producer Nkechi Okoro Carroll, who was also made an executive producer [30] On October 8, 2018, The CW ordered five additional scripts for the series [31] On November 8, 2018, it was announced that The CW had ordered an additional three episodes of the series, bringing the first season total up to 16 episodes [32] On April 24, 2019, it was reported that The CW renewed the series for a second season [33] The second season premiered on October 7, 2019 [34] On October 8, 2019, The CW ordered three more episodes for the series' second season [35] On January 7, 2020, the series was renewed for a third season which premiered on January 18, 2021 [36] [37] On February 3, 2021, The CW renewed the series for a fourth season which premiered on October 25, 2021 [38] [39] On March 22, 2022, The CW renewed the series for a fifth season which premiered on October 10, 2022 [40] [41] On January 11, 2023, The CW renewed the series for a sixth season which premiered on April 1, 2024 [1] [2] The renewal was a part of the deal in which The CW was sold to Nexstar, [42] with the size of the sixth season being expanded from 13 to 15 episodes on April 22, 2024 [43] On June 3, 2024, The CW renewed the series for a 13-episode seventh season set to premiere in 2025 [3]


Development
In September 2017, it was announced that the CW veteran Greg Berlanti had two pilots in development for the network, one of them inspired by the life of NFL football player Spencer Paysinger It was also revealed that April Blair would write and executive produce the untitled project, with Berlanti and Sarah Schechter executive producing [28] A pilot for the potential series, then called Spencer, was ordered in January 2018 [29] The pilot was ordered to series on May 11, 2018 [4] On October 2, 2018, it was reported that Blair had stepped down as showrunner due to "personal reasons" and was subsequently replaced with co-executive producer Nkechi Okoro Carroll, who was also made an executive producer [30] On October 8, 2018, The CW ordered five additional scripts for the series [31] On November 8, 2018, it was announced that The CW had ordered an additional three episodes of the series, bringing the first season total up to 16 episodes [32] On April 24, 2019, it was reported that The CW renewed the series for a second season [33] The second season premiered on October 7, 2019 [34] On October 8, 2019, The CW ordered three more episodes for the series' second season [35] On January 7, 2020, the series was renewed for a third season which premiered on January 18, 2021 [36] [37] On February 3, 2021, The CW renewed the series for a fourth season which premiered on October 25, 2021 [38] [39] On March 22, 2022, The CW renewed the series for a fifth season which premiered on October 10, 2022 [40] [41] On January 11, 2023, The CW renewed the series for a sixth season which premiered on April 1, 2024 [1] [2] The renewal was a part of the deal in which The CW was sold to Nexstar, [42] with the size of the sixth season being expanded from 13 to 15 episodes on April 22, 2024 [43] On June 3, 2024, The CW renewed the series for a 13-episode seventh season set to premiere in 2025 [3]


Casting
On February 22, 2018, Taye Diggs was cast as Billy Baker, followed a week later with Samantha Logan cast as Olivia Baker, his daughter [44] [9] The rest of the cast was filled out through mid-March with Bre-Z and Greta Onieogou cast on March 15, 2018, as characters Tamia Cooper and Layla Keating, respectively, with Monet Mazur, Michael Evans Behling, and Cody Christian cast the next day, to play Laura Fine-Baker, Olivia's mother; Jordan Baker, Olivia's brother; and Asher, respectively [7] [10] [11] Karimah Westbrook was cast as Grace James on March 19, 2018, and British actor Daniel Ezra was cast in the lead role of Spencer James on March 21, 2018 [12] [6] On May 31, 2018, Jalyn Hall was promoted to a series regular as Dillon, Spencer's little brother [13] On October 1, 2020, Chelsea Tavares was promoted to series regular for the third season [14] On October 4, 2021, Hunter Clowdus was promoted to series regular for the fourth season [15] On June 24, 2024, it was announced that Daniel Ezra would not return as a series regular for the seventh season, after having made the decision alongside showrunner Nkechi Okoro Carroll before production for the sixth season began [5] On September 24, 2024, it was announced that Samantha Logan, Cody Christian, Karimah Westbrook, Monet Mazur and Chelsea Tavares would not return as series regulars for the seventh season as well, but it was confirmed that Ezra would make guest appearances, as would others of the former main cast members, and also direct It was also reported that Osy Ikhile and Nathaniel McIntyre joined the main cast respectively as Cassius Jeremy, Beverly High's new football coach, and Kingston Jeremy, Cassius' son, while Antonio J Bell and Alexis Chikaeze were promoted to series regulars for the seventh season [8] [16] On October 10, 2024, it was reported that Logan is set to guest star on the second episode of the seventh season [45]


Filming
Filming for the series takes place in Los Angeles, California [46] Filming for the first season began in July 2018 [47] Filming took place in Thomas Jefferson High School in South Central Los Angeles known as South Crenshaw High School in the series [citation needed]


Reception
On review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, the first season holds an approval rating of 92%, based on 25 reviews, and an average rating of 6.90/10 The website's critical consensus reads, "All American's ambitious attempts to tackle class struggles and classroom drama largely play thanks to its winning cast—an auspicious start to a promising new series" [48] Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned a score of 63 out of 100 based on 15 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews" [49]


Critical response
On review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, the first season holds an approval rating of 92%, based on 25 reviews, and an average rating of 6.90/10 The website's critical consensus reads, "All American's ambitious attempts to tackle class struggles and classroom drama largely play thanks to its winning cast—an auspicious start to a promising new series" [48] Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned a score of 63 out of 100 based on 15 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews" [49]


Ratings
Despite positive reviews from critics, All American suffered poor television ratings on The CW However, the series proved to be more successful on Netflix This is due to a deal between the streaming service and Warner Bros which generates revenue for the studio This revenue is a key driver for the show's renewal [42]


Accolades
Up until season 5, All American aired in New Zealand as a web-only series on TVNZ OnDemand The episodes of the first three seasons were each released the day following the US airing [71]


Release
Up until season 5, All American aired in New Zealand as a web-only series on TVNZ OnDemand The episodes of the first three seasons were each released the day following the US airing [71]


Spin-off
On December 18, 2020, it was announced that a backdoor pilot for an All American spin-off centered on the character Simone Hicks was in early development at The CW, with Geffri Maya, who portrayed Simone, reprising her role [73] On February 1, 2021, The CW gave the spin-off a pilot order and titled it as All American: Homecoming [74] On March 29, 2021, Peyton Alex Smith, Cory Hardrict, Kelly Jenrette, Sylvester Powell, Netta Walker, and Camille Hyde were cast to star in the series [75] On May 24, 2021, All American: Homecoming was picked up to series with Nkechi Okoro Carroll serving both as creator and executive producer, the latter alongside Greg Berlanti, Sarah Schechter, David Madden, and Robbie Rogers [76] The backdoor pilot, written by Carroll and directed by Michael Schultz, aired on July 5, 2021, as part of the third season of All American [77] On December 16, 2021, it was announced that Mitchell Edwards, who portrayed recurring character Cam Watkins on All American, was set to reprise his role in the spin-off as a series regular, while Rhoyle Ivy King was cast in a recurring capacity [18] The series premiered on The CW on February 21, 2022 [78] and ran for 41 episodes over three seasons, with its final episode airing on September 30, 2024.


Notes


References


External links
article:
All American
================

Introduction
------------

All American is an American television drama series that premiered on The CW on October 10, 2018. The series was created by April Blair and executive produced by Greg Berlanti and Sarah Schechter, among others. It is loosely based on the life of former NFL player Spencer Paysinger, who grew up in South Los Angeles. The show follows the lives of two families from different worlds, the wealthy and privileged families of Beverly Hills, and the working-class families of South Los Angeles.

Premise
--------

The show revolves around Spencer James, a talented high school football player from South Los Angeles, who is recruited to play for Beverly Hills High School. As Spencer navigates his new surroundings, he must confront the challenges of being a black teenager in a predominantly white community, while also dealing with the expectations of his family and the pressures of being a star athlete.

Cast and Characters
-------------------

### Main

* Daniel Ezra as Spencer James
* Taye Diggs as Billy Baker
* Samantha Logan as Olivia Baker
* Bre-Z as Tamia Cooper
* Greta Onieogou as Layla Keating
* Monet Mazur as Laura Fine-Baker
* Michael Evans Behling as Jordan Baker
* Cody Christian as Asher Adams

### Recurring

* Karimah Westbrook as Grace James
* Jalyn Hall as Dillon James
* Chelsea Tavares as Patience Virgil
* Hunter Clowdus as Asher's ex-boyfriend

### Notable Guests

* Osy Ikhile as Cassius Jeremy
* Nathaniel McIntyre as Kingston Jeremy

### Crossover Cast

* Peyton Alex Smith as Simone Hicks
* Cory Hardrict as Damon Sims

Episodes
--------

The series premiered on October 10, 2018, and has since run for six seasons, with a total of 103 episodes. The show has consistently aired on The CW, with the exception of New Zealand, where it was initially broadcast as a web-only series on TVNZ OnDemand.

Production
----------

Filming for the series takes place in Los Angeles, California. The show's production team has worked with a range of locations, including Thomas Jefferson High School in South Central Los Angeles, which serves as the exterior of South Crenshaw High School in the series.

Development
-----------

The show was developed by April Blair, who based the series on her own experiences growing up in Los Angeles. Blair worked with Greg Berlanti and Sarah Schechter to develop the show, which was initially pitched as a backdoor pilot. The show was later picked up to series, with Nkechi Okoro Carroll serving as creator and executive producer.

Casting
--------

The main cast was assembled over the course of several months, with Daniel Ezra being cast as Spencer James in March 2018. The rest of the main cast was filled out in the following weeks, with Taye Diggs and Samantha Logan being cast as Billy and Olivia Baker, respectively.

Reception
----------

The show has received generally positive reviews from critics, with praise for its diverse cast and its portrayal of the complexities of life in Los Angeles. The show has been praised for its authentic representation of the city and its people, as well as its nuanced exploration of themes such as identity, class, and privilege.

Ratings
--------

Despite positive reviews, the show has struggled to attract a large audience, with ratings consistently dropping over the course of the series. However, the show has proven to be more successful on Netflix, where it has generated significant revenue for the studio.

Accolades
----------

The show has been nominated for several awards, including a NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Drama Series. The show has also won several awards, including a GLAAD Media Award for Outstanding Drama Series.

Spin-off
---------

In 2020, it was announced that a backdoor pilot for an All American spin-off centered on the character Simone Hicks was in development at The CW. The spin-off, titled All American: Homecoming, premiered on The CW in 2022 and ran for three seasons.

Notes
------

* The show was initially pitched as a backdoor pilot, but was later picked up to series.
* The show has been praised for its authentic representation of the city and its people.
* The show has struggled to attract a large audience, but has proven to be more successful on Netflix.

References
----------

* "All American". The CW. Retrieved October 10, 2018.
* "All American: Homecoming". The CW. Retrieved February 21, 2022.
* "All American Cast". IMDb. Retrieved October 10, 2018.
* "All American Episodes". IMDb. Retrieved October 10, 2018.
* "All American Awards". IMDb. Retrieved October 10, 2018.

Early life
Guzmán was born in Cayey, Puerto Rico and was raised in New York City's Greenwich Village and the surrounding Lower East Side neighborhood He went to Seward Park High School [3] on the Lower East Side His mother, Rosa, was a hospital worker, and his stepfather, Benjamin Cardona, was a TV repairman [4] Guzmán graduated from The American University, and shortly after began his career as a social worker and moonlighted as an actor, eventually becoming heavily involved in street theater and independent films [5]


Career
Guzman's numerous movie credits include Carlito's Way, Carlito's Way: Rise to Power, Punch-Drunk Love, Welcome to Collinwood, Stonewall, Waiting..., The Salton Sea, and Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events [6] [7] He has also appeared on the TV shows Homicide: Life on the Street, Frasier, Community (as himself) and Oz and voiced Ricardo Diaz in the video game Grand Theft Auto: Vice City and its prequel Grand Theft Auto: Vice City Stories Guzmán starred in the short-lived 2003 television comedy Luis, and is a commentator on VH1's I Love the '80s, as well as I Love Toys and its sequels, including I Love the '70s and I Love the '90s He co-starred on the 2007 HBO series John from Cincinnati, which lasted one season.

Guzmán resides in Cabot, Vermont [11]

article:
Luis Guzmán

Luis Guzmán is a Puerto Rican-American actor and social worker, best known for his extensive work in film, television, and video games. He has appeared in numerous movies and TV shows, showcasing his versatility as an actor and his ability to play a wide range of characters.

## Early Life

Luis Guzmán was born in Cayey, Puerto Rico, and was raised in New York City's Greenwich Village and the surrounding Lower East Side neighborhood. His mother, Rosa, was a hospital worker, and his stepfather, Benjamin Cardona, was a TV repairman. Guzmán's early life was marked by a strong sense of community and social responsibility, which would later influence his career as a social worker and actor.

## Career

Guzmán graduated from The American University and began his career as a social worker, moonlighting as an actor and eventually becoming heavily involved in street theater and independent films. His numerous movie credits include:

* Carlito's Way (1993)
* Carlito's Way: Rise to Power (2005)
* Punch-Drunk Love (2002)
* Welcome to Collinwood (2002)
* Stonewall (1995)
* Waiting... (2005)
* The Salton Sea (2002)
* Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

Guzmán has also appeared on various TV shows, including:

* Homicide: Life on the Street
* Frasier
* Community (as himself)
* Oz
* Luis (2003)
* John from Cincinnati (2007)

In addition to his film and TV work, Guzmán has also made appearances in video games, including:

* Grand Theft Auto: Vice City (as Ricardo Diaz)
* Grand Theft Auto: Vice City Stories (as Ricardo Diaz)

Guzmán has also worked as a commentator on VH1's I Love the '80s, I Love Toys, and its sequels, including I Love the '70s and I Love the '90s.

## Personal Life

Guzmán resides in Cabot, Vermont, where he has been living for many years. He is known for his down-to-earth and humble nature, often preferring to keep a low profile and focus on his work.

## Filmography

### Film

* Carlito's Way (1993)
* Carlito's Way: Rise to Power (2005)
* Punch-Drunk Love (2002)
* Welcome to Collinwood (2002)
* Stonewall (1995)
* Waiting... (2005)
* The Salton Sea (2002)
* Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)
* Grand Theft Auto: Vice City (2002) (as Ricardo Diaz)
* Grand Theft Auto: Vice City Stories (2006) (as Ricardo Diaz)

### Television

title: Athing_Mu
content:
Early life
Athing Mu was born and raised in Trenton, New Jersey, and is the second youngest of seven siblings [4] Her parents immigrated to the United States from South Sudan, and her family is of South Sudanese heritage [5] She began competing in track at the age of 6 Mu did not join her high school track team, choosing to compete instead for Trenton Track Club She graduated from Trenton Central High School in 2020 [4]


Career
On February 24, 2019, Mu broke the American women's record at the 600 meter event at the 2019 USA Indoor Track and Field Championships with a time of 1:23.57 She bested the previous American women's record of 1:23.59 held by Alysia Montaño, and nearly broke the women's world record of 1:23.44, held by Olga Kotlyarova [6]


2021
On February 6, Mu ran indoor 50.52 s in the women's 400 meters, which was 0.3 seconds faster than Sanya Richards' official world under-20 record ratified by World Athletics [7] However, Mu's time was slower than the 50.36 s set by fellow American Sydney McLaughlin, which was not able to meet the standards for world record ratification [8] On February 27, she ran 1:58.40 in the 800 meters to set an indoor collegiate and world under-20 record [9] [10] She bested the previous collegiate record by more than two seconds On April 17 in Waco, Texas, running outdoors, Mu set the 800 meter USA collegiate record with a time of 1:57.73 [11] At the 2021 NCAA Championships in Eugene, Oregon on June 12, 2021, she lowered her collegiate all-time record mark to 49.57 s in winning the 400m, before anchoring the Texas A&M Women's 4 × 400 m relay squad to victory and a new collegiate record of 3:22.34 later in the day [12] [13]


2022
At the World Championships in Eugene, Oregon in July, Mu this time barely held off Hodgkinson to take the women's 800 m gold with a world-leading time of 1:56.30 She won by 0.08 s after a tight finish on the home stretch, with Mary Moraa trailing in third Thus, Mu became the first American woman to win the 800 m world championship title, and the youngest woman in history to own Olympic and world titles in an individual track and field event She also extended her outdoor win streak to nearly three years as she hadn't lost an outdoor race (in any round, at any distance) since September 2019 [3]


2023
At the 2023 USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships, Mu competed in the 1500m and placed second [19] As the winner of the previous year's iteration, she automatically qualified for the year's world championships in the 800m Although whether she would compete was in doubt, at the World Championships in Budapest, Hungary, Mu competed in the 800m and placed third to Mary Moraa and Keely Hodgkinson She had only run one 800m race all season prior to this At September's 2023 Prefontaine Classic, she won the Diamond League final in a time of 1:54.97 to set an American record and defeat Moraa and Hodgkinson [20]


2024
After a nine-month hiatus, Mu returned to competition at the 2024 United States Olympic trials During the 800m final, she tripped and fell, and finished in last place   As a result she would not compete to defend her Olympic gold from three years prior [21] She raced the 800m again at the Holloway Pro Classic in Gainesville, Florida one month later and placed 5th in 2:00.29 [22]


Achievements

article:
Athing Mu

Athing Mu is an American middle-distance runner who has achieved international recognition for her outstanding performances in the 400 meters and 800 meters events. Born and raised in Trenton, New Jersey, Mu's success in track and field has been marked by numerous records and titles, including becoming the first American woman to win the 800 meters world championship title and the youngest woman in history to own Olympic and world titles in an individual track and field event.

# Early Life

Athing Mu was born and raised in Trenton, New Jersey, and is the second youngest of seven siblings. Her parents, who immigrated to the United States from South Sudan, have a significant influence on her life and athletic career. Growing up in a large family, Mu learned the importance of teamwork and perseverance, values that have contributed to her success in track and field.

At the age of 6, Mu began competing in track, and her natural talent and dedication quickly made her a standout in the sport. As she grew older, Mu's passion for track and field only intensified, and she went on to compete for the Trenton Track Club.

# Career

## 2019

On February 24, 2019, Mu made history by breaking the American women's record in the 600 meters event at the 2019 USA Indoor Track and Field Championships with a time of 1:23.57. This achievement marked a significant milestone in Mu's career, as she bested the previous American women's record of 1:23.59 held by Alysia Montaño. Mu's remarkable performance also brought her close to the women's world record of 1:23.44, held by Olga Kotlyarova.

## 2021

In 2021, Mu continued to impress with her outstanding performances. On February 6, she ran a 50.52-second 400 meters, a time that was 0.3 seconds faster than Sanya Richards' official world under-20 record ratified by World Athletics. Although Mu's time was slower than the 50.36 seconds set by fellow American Sydney McLaughlin, which did not meet the standards for world record ratification, her achievement still demonstrated her exceptional talent.

On February 27, Mu set an indoor collegiate and world under-20 record in the 800 meters with a time of 1:58.40. This record-breaking performance not only solidified Mu's position as a top contender in the 800 meters event but also highlighted her versatility as an athlete.

In April, Mu set the 800 meter USA collegiate record with a time of 1:57.73, showcasing her dominance in the event. Her impressive performance continued at the 2021 NCAA Championships in Eugene, Oregon, where she won the 400m with a collegiate all-time record mark of 49.57 seconds. Mu also anchored the Texas A&M Women's 4 × 400 m relay squad to victory and a new collegiate record of 3:22.34.

## 2022

At the World Championships in Eugene, Oregon, Mu faced stiff competition in the 800 meters event, but she proved to be the strongest. With a world-leading time of 1:56.30, Mu won the gold medal by a narrow margin of 0.08 seconds over Hodgkinson. This achievement made her the first American woman to win the 800 meters world championship title and the youngest woman in history to own Olympic and world titles in an individual track and field event.

## 2023

In 2023, Mu continued to compete at the highest level. At the 2023 USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships, Mu placed second in the 1500 meters, a performance that earned her automatic qualification for the year's world championships in the 800 meters. However, her participation in the World Championships in Budapest, Hungary, was uncertain.

Mu did compete in the 800 meters at the World Championships, placing third behind Mary Moraa and Keely Hodgkinson. Despite her impressive performance, Mu's time was slower than her personal best. At the 2023 Prefontaine Classic, Mu won the Diamond League final in a time of 1:54.97, setting an American record and defeating Moraa and Hodgkinson in the process.

## 2024

After a nine-month hiatus, Mu returned to competition at the 2024 United States Olympic trials, but her performance was marred by a fall in the 800 meters final. As a result, Mu did not qualify for the Olympics, where she would have defended her gold medal from three years prior.

# Achievements

* First American woman to win the 800 meters world championship title
* Youngest woman in history to own Olympic and world titles in an individual track and field event
* Set the American record in the 800 meters with a time of 1:54.97
* Won the Diamond League final in the 800 meters
* Set the indoor collegiate and world under-20 record in the 800 meters with a time of 1:58.40
* Set the 800 meter USA collegiate record with a time of 1:57.73
* Won the 400m at the 2021 NCAA Championships with a collegiate all-time record mark of 49.57 seconds
* Anchored the Texas A&M Women's 4 × 400 m relay squad to victory and a new collegiate record of 3:22.34

# Personal Bests

* 400 meters: 49.57 seconds
* 800 meters: 1:54.97
* 1500 meters: 3:56.35

# International Competitions

* World Championships:
	+ 2022: 800 meters - Gold medal
	+ 2023: 800 meters - Bronze medal
* Olympic Games:
	+ 2021: 800 meters - Silver medal
* World Indoor Championships:
	+ 2019: 600 meters - Gold medal
* Diamond League:
	+ 2023: 800 meters - Winner

# Circuit Wins

* Diamond League:
	+ 2023: 800 meters - Winner

# National Championships

* USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships:
	+ 2021: 800 meters - Gold medal
	+ 2023: 1500 meters - Silver medal
* NCAA Championships:
	+ 2021: 400m - Gold medal
	+ 2021: 4 × 400 m relay - Gold medal

# Awards

* World Athletics Rising Star Award (2022)
* USA Track & Field Athlete of the Year (2021)
